The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow taxpayers to request mediation or arbitration in any case unless the Secretary has specifically excluded the issue or class of cases. Independent mediators will be involved in the process. Taxpayers can elect to have mediation conducted by an independent, neutral individual not employed by the Office of Appeals. They must share the costs equally with the Office of Appeals and select a mediator from a recognized roster of neutral mediators. Taxpayers can choose mediation by neutral mediators, except for individuals or small businesses with income below 250% of the poverty level. The amendment allows for the opportunity to elect mediation or arbitration at the time of filing with the Office of Appeals or before deliberations begin. Effective upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 9. EXTENSION OF TIME FOR CONTESTING IRS LEVY. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend the time for returning property subject to levy from 9 months to 3 years. Effective for levies made after the enactment date of the Act or before if the 9-month period has not expired. SEC. 10. WAIVER OF INSTALLMENT AGREEMENT FEE. The Secretary will waive fees for installment agreements for taxpayers with adjusted gross income below 250 percent of the poverty level who agree to make payments electronically. Effective upon enactment. The amendment to section 6015 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for the suspension of the filing period for spousal relief petitions in cases under title 11, United States Code. This suspension lasts for the duration of the prohibition from filing a petition and an additional 60 days. The amendment to section 6015 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for the suspension of the filing period for spousal relief petitions in cases under title 11, United States Code, after the enactment of this Act. Additionally, subsection (d) of section 6330 is amended to allow taxpayers to petition the Tax Court for review of determinations in collection proceedings. The amendment allows for the suspension of the filing period for petitions in title 11 cases under the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment also changes subsection (c) of section 6320. These amendments apply to petitions filed under section 6330 after the enactment of the Act. VENUE FOR APPEAL OF SPOUSAL RELIEF AND COLLECTION CASES. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code regarding venue for appeal of spousal relief and collection cases, including specifying the legal residence or principal place of business for petitioners under different sections. The amendments made by this section apply to petitions filed after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 13 increases monetary penalties for unauthorized disclosures of information in the Internal Revenue Code to $10,000. The amendment applies to disclosures made after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 14 allows de novo Tax Court review of claims for equitable innocent spouse relief. SEC. 14 allows de novo Tax Court review of claims for equitable innocent spouse relief. SEC. 15 prohibits the IRS from raising new issues in an internal appeal. The Internal Revenue Service Office of Appeals may only review issues within the scope of the initial determination. Certain matters, such as issues not raised in a notice of deficiency or new tax deficiencies, are deemed outside the scope. This section does not limit taxpayers from raising issues. The IRS Office of Appeals can only review issues within the initial determination scope. Taxpayers are not limited in raising issues on appeal. The IRS Office of Appeals is prohibited from raising new issues in an internal appeal. This amendment applies to matters filed or pending with the IRS Office of Appeals after the enactment of this Act.
